Description.val:
Provides weapons and combat vehicle improvements in the areas of survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Additionally, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) and upgrades address current and future reliability, sustainability, maintainability, and obsolescence issues to ensure mission readiness and effectiveness on the battlefield.

M1A1 MOD KIT: The M1A1 Mod Kit line sustains and improves the technology of the M1A1 tank and Armored Vehicle Launched Bridge (AVLB) to provide the MAGTF with the most relevant armor protected firepower, shock effect and maneuver platforms. Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support these platforms.

Assault Bridging Modernization Program: Replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) maneuver. This program will establish commonality across the DoD fleet, eliminates obsolescence and diminishing manufacturing sources and materiel shortfall issues, while increasing the operational effectiveness and readiness of the MAGTF.

IRV:  The Improved Recovery Vehicle (also known as the M88A2 Hercules) is the Marine Air-Ground Task Force's heavy lift, recovery, and battlefield maintenance asset in support of Marine Corps mobile assets (ie. ACV, AAV, LAV, ARV) whose organic recovery capability is exceeded by the vehicle weight.  This line is designed to sustain and improve the technology of the IRV.  Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support the IRV.

Justification.val:
FY 2019:  $22.904M.  

FY 2019 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.971 (Active $12.580M; Reserves $2.391M): 
These funds support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (Active and Reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Funds support the procurement of efforts such as, Improved Side Armor (ISA), Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP), and Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM).  ISA is a modification that significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank.  GPSLP is a modification to the tank's fire control system that enables the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle.  TCM supports the procurement of new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded. 

FY 2019 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.700M:   
These funds support the procurement of 1 Test Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.  

FY 2019 IRV $2.233M (Active $2.022M; Reserves $0.211M): 
These funds support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform.  Additionally, this funding supports modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.

FY 2020: $22.760M

FY 2020 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.439 (Active $12.641M; Reserves $1.798M): 
These funds continue to support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (Active and Reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility and command and control.  Funds in support of survivability efforts allow for the procurement of Improved Side Armor (ISA) which significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank.  Funds in support of lethality efforts procure a new Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP).  This modification to the tank's fire control system will enable the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle.  Funds for the command and control effort procure communication systems as part of the Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM) effort.  TCM procures new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded.  Funds for installation kits support the capabilities efforts of survivability, lethality, and command and control.  These funds procure the cables, mounting hardware, installation material, and labor for the Abrams Integrated Display and Targeting System (AIDATS), ISA, and TCM installation process.  The decrease from FY19 to FY20 is attributed to the reduction in level of effort for Command and Control which consists of Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM).

FY 2020 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.700M:   
These funds support the procurement of 1 Production Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.  

FY 2020 IRV $2.621M (Active $2.406M; Reserves $0.215M): 
These funds will support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform.  Funding increase from FY19 to FY20 of $.298M will support modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.

FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $3.067M

FY 2021 M1A1 MOD KIT $0.000M: 
The net decrease of $14.439M from FY20 to FY21 is a result of service decision to transition the M1A1 program to full sustainment and stop modernization.

FY 2021 IRV $3.067 (Active $2.848M; Reserves $0.219M):
These funds will continue to procure modification kits and associated system technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform. This line is designed to sustain and improve the technology of the IRV.  Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support the IRV.Funding increase from FY20 to FY21 of $0.446M will support the integration on WIN 10 operating systems into the DSESTS, Electronic Maintenance Support System (EMSS) with combined application platform/software loader verification, and the completion of Exterior Stowage Modification Kits.

Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
